{{pp-pc1|expiry=August 27, 2019}} {{pp-pc}} {{Use Indian English|date=December 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2015}} {{Infobox Indian politician | name = Adhir Ranjan Chowdhury | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1956|04|02|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Baharampur|Behrampore]], [[Murshidabad]], [[West Bengal]], [[India]] | residence = 9, Haribabu Lane
P.O.-[[Cossimbazar]]
[[Baharampur|Berhampore]] - 2
[[West Bengal]]- 742102 | death_date = | death_place = | office1 = [[Member of Parliament (India)|Member]] of the [[Indian Parliament]]
for [[Berhampore (Lok Sabha constituency)|Berhampore]] |term_start1 = 1999 |term_end1 = | office2 = | successor2 = | office3 = [[Union Minister|Union Minister of State for Railways]] | term_start3 = 28 October 2012 | term_end3 = 16 May 2014 | profession = [[Social Reformer]] cum Politician | spouse = Sreemati A. Chowdhury | children = Hoimonti (daughter) | footnotes = | date = | year = | source = }} '''Adhir Ranjan Chowdhury''' (born 2 April 1956) was born in a [[Bengali people|Bengali family]] is currently a member of the [[16th Lok Sabha]] of [[India]]. He represents the [[Berhampore (Lok Sabha constituency)|Berhampore]] constituency of [[West Bengal]] and is a member of the [[Indian National Congress]] (INC) political party.[http://westbengalelectionresult.com/adhir-chowdhury-congress-leader-political-profilecontact-blogs-news-address/285 Adhir Chowdhury -Political Profile] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101206144334/http://westbengalelectionresult.com/adhir-chowdhury-congress-leader-political-profilecontact-blogs-news-address/285 |date=6 December 2010 }} Adhir Chowdhury -Political Profile ==Political career== He became MLA in 1996 and MP in 1999. The District Congress president, Shri Adhir was widely considered the chief architect of party's victory in zila parishad elections as also in elections to various municipalities in Murshidabad district.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} When Chowdhury has contested the Berhampore Lok Sabha seat, nobody expected him to win as Berhampore had not been won by the Congress since 1951 and was an RSP stronghold. He has won the Berhampore Lok Sabha seat consecutively since 1999. He took the initiative in the election campaigns of Pranab Mukherjee from Jangipur parliamentary constituency in Murshidabad district in 2004 and also in 2009 which won him the favour of the Congress high command.He was also responsible for the recent election of [[President of India|President]] [[Pranab Mukherjee|Pranab's]] son [[Abhijit Mukherjee]] from the Jangipur Lok Sabha seat.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} On 28 October 2012 he was inducted in the Union Ministry under Prime Minister Shri Manmohan Singh as Minister of State for Railways.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} After taking charge as Minister of State for Railways, he has reviewed the statutes of safety, punctuality and passenger amenities with Board Members and inspected Sealdah, Howrah, Beharampur etc. railway stations to check adequacy of passenger amenity facilities. He became the president of [[West Bengal Pradesh Congress Committee|West Bengal Pradesh Congress]] on 10 February 2014.{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kolkata/In-tough-message-Cong-makes-Adhir-Chowdhury-PCC-chief/articleshow/30180087.cms|title=In tough message, Cong makes Adhir Chowdhury PCC chief - Times of India|publisher=|accessdate=20 September 2016}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20040907205217/http://164.100.24.208/ls/lsmember/biodata.asp?mpsno=97 Official biographical sketch in Parliament of India website ('''cache site''')] {{16th LS members from West Bengal}} {{15th LS members from West Bengal}} {{Eleventh to Fourteenth Lok Sabha, West Bengal}} {{West Bengal Legislative Assembly2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chowdhury, Adhir Ranjan}} [[Category:1956 births]] [[Category:Indian National Congress politicians from West Bengal]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Murshidabad district]] [[Category:14th Lok Sabha members]] [[Category:15th Lok Sabha members]] [[Category:Lok Sabha members from West Bengal]] [[Category:Bengali people]] [[Category:16th Lok Sabha members]] [[Category:13th Lok Sabha members]]

revision.text: #REDIRECT[[List of Hustle characters#Albert Stroller]] [[Category:Fictional criminals|Con artists, Fictional]]

'''Alejo Calatayud''' (c. 1705 – January 31, 1731) was a Mestizo silversmith from Oropesa, [[Cochabamba]] province in present-day [[Bolivia]]. In 1730 Calatayud led a violent rebellion, and became a local hero amongst the plebeian masses of the province.<ref name="go">González Moscoso, René. ''Historia de las ideas políticas en el mundo y en Bolivia''. Sucre, Bolivia: Editorial "Tupac Katari", 1989. pp. 125-126</ref>
Calatayud belonged to the sector of educated Mestizos, and was a member of the silversmiths' guild.<ref name="na"/><ref name="le"/> On December 1, 1730, he led a rebellion in Oropesa, in response to rumours that an official named Manuel Benero de Belaro had been sent to ensure that the Mestizos paid the same punitive taxes as the indigenous population.<ref name="go"/> Calatayud was twenty-five years old at the time.<ref name="le">Glick, Thomas F., Miguel Angel Puig-Samper, and Rosaura Ruiz. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=ViZpP_ildjYC&pg=PA212 The Reception of Darwinism in the Iberian World: Spain, Spanish America, and Brazil]''. Dordrecht: Kluwer Academic, 2001. p. 212</ref> The rebellion united the Mestizos and the indigenous people and spread to the entire Cochabamba province.<ref name="go"/> The provincial capital was surrounded and seized by Calatayud's forces.<ref name="na">Salomon, Frank, Stuart B. Schwartz, Bruce G. Trigger, Wilcomb E. Washburn, Richard E. W. Adams, and Murdo J. MacLeod. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=TuxGG6pXs-QC&pg=PA530 The Cambridge History of the Native Peoples of the Americas]''. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1996. p. 530</ref>
The 1730 rebellion was characterized by an intersection of ethnic and class conflicts.<ref name="na"/> The rebels ransacked shops and houses and killed 39 Spanish inhabitants of the town. However, once the clergy took to the streets with the sacrament the Mestizo rebels stopped further bloodshed. Two representatives of the creole elite were elected as magistrates.<ref name="br">Brading, D. A. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=vQdyHIKrqJYC&pg=PA408 The First America: The Spanish Monarchy, Creole Patriots, and the Liberal State, 1492-1867]''. Cambridge [England]: Cambridge University Press, 1991. p. 408</ref> Because the insurgency was badly organized it could not withstand the counter-attack organized by the creole elite (actioned by the magistrates of Cochabamba). A force led by Rodrígez Carrasco captured and decapitated Calatayud, sending his head to the [[Royal Audience of Charcas]]. Rodrígez Carrasco also issued death warrants against twenty-two of Calatayud's followers.<ref name="go"/><ref name="br"/>
The revolt led by Calatayud was important for the political development in the area, as it marked the start of a series of revolts that lasted for half a century.<ref name="br"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Calatayud, Alejo}} [[Category:1700s births]] [[Category:1731 deaths]] [[Category:Mestizo people]] [[Category:People from Cochabamba Department]] [[Category:Silversmiths]] [[Category:Rebels]] [[Category:Executed Bolivian people]] [[Category:People executed by New Spain]] [[Category:People executed by Spain by decapitation]]

revision.text:
{{External links|date= May 2017}} {{Infobox criminal | name = Bill Longley | image = WilliamPrestonLongley.jpg | image_size = 220px | alt = | caption = | nationality = [[United States|American]] | birth_name = William Preston Longley | birth_date = {{Birth date|1851|10|06}} | birth_place = [[Austin County, Texas]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1878|10|11|1851|10|06}} | death_place = [[Giddings, Texas]] | alias = Wild Bill | conviction = Murder | conviction_penalty = Death by hanging | conviction_status = Deceased | parents = Campbell and Sarah Longley }}
'''William Preston Longley''' (October 6, 1851 – October 11, 1878), also known as '''Wild Bill Longley''', was an [[United States|American]] [[American Old West|Old West]] [[outlaw]] and [[gunslinger|gunfighter]] noted for his ruthless nature, speed with a gun, quick temper, and unpredictable demeanor. He is considered to have been one of the deadliest gunfighters in the Old West.
== Early life == Bill Longley was born on Mill Creek in [[Austin County, Texas]], the sixth of ten children of Campbell and Sarah Longley. His family moved when he was two years old and he was raised on a farm near [[Lincoln, Texas|Old Evergreen, Texas]], in present-day Lincoln, [[Lee County, Texas]], where he spent a large part of his childhood learning to shoot.<ref name="gunfighters">{{cite book | title = Encyclopedia of Western Gunfighters| last = O'Neal| first = Bill| year = 1979| publisher = University of Oklahoma Press| isbn = 0-8061-1508-4| pages = 192–194}}</ref> He received an average education for the time. He was six feet (183 cm) tall with a thin build, jet black hair, and was just reaching adulthood when the [[American Civil War]] ended in 1865.
By 1867, [[Texas]] was fully under the control of the [[Union Army|Union]] due to the [[Reconstruction Act]]. The military acted in all capacities, including law enforcement, which caused considerable resentment throughout the state. Around this time, Longley dropped out of school and began living a wild life, drinking, and running in the company of others of a similar disposition.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Miller |first1=Rick |title=Boastful Bill Longley: Cold-blooded Texas Killer |url=http://historynet.com/we/bllongley/index.html |website=historynet.com |publisher=Wild West Magazine |accessdate=19 September 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060526123117/http://historynet.com/we/bllongley/index.html |archivedate=May 26, 2006 |date=May 26, 2006 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
==First murders in Texas== In 1867 the Longley family farm was just one mile from the [[El Camino Real de los Tejas|Camino Real]], an old [[Spain|Spanish]] royal highway that joined [[San Antonio]] and [[Nacogdoches, Texas]].
In mid-December 1868, three former [[History of slavery in the United States|slaves]] named Green Evans, Pryer Evans, and the third known only as Ned, rode through Evergreen, intending evidently to visit friends further south. Longley, accompanied by a couple of friends, forced the three men at gunpoint into a dry creek bed. Green Evans panicked and spurred his horse to escape. Longley shot at him several times, killing him.
Longley and his friends went through the dead man's pockets, as Pryer Evans and Ned rode away. Although given sole responsibility for the murder, Longley later claimed that he was not the only one shooting. Longley's account of this murder differs from that of his later killings, where he was more inclined to brag about shooting men than to try to divert blame to others. Some versions of Green's killing claim he was a member of the [[Texas State Police]]; the TSP only existed from 1870 to 1873.
Longley drifted around Texas for a time, and while gambling in [[Western saloon|saloon]]s he became acquainted with noted gambler, [[Phil Coe]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fcocy |title=Coe, Philip Houston |website=tshaonline.org|accessdate=September 19, 2016}}</ref> In 1869, Longley and his brother-in-law, John Wilson, embarked on a crime spree through southern Texas. Together they robbed settlers and in one instance killed a freed slave named Paul Brice in [[Bastrop County, Texas]], after which they stole his horses. They also reportedly killed a freed slave woman in Evergreen.
In March 1870, a $1,000 reward for their capture was offered by the Union military authority. Longley later claimed that Wilson was killed by outlaws in 1870 in [[Brazos County, Texas]], although conflicting evidence suggests he was killed in 1874 in [[Falls County, Texas]].
==U.S. Cavalry career== Longley left Texas and moved north to avoid the authorities and by May 1870, he had joined a gold-hunting party in [[Cheyenne, Wyoming]].
The gold mining party travelled into the [[Black Hills]] of [[South Dakota]], but a treaty with the [[Sioux]] prohibited mining, and the party disbanded when intercepted by a U.S. [[cavalry]] unit. On June 22, 1870, Longley enlisted for a five-year commitment in the army, joining Company B of the [[U.S. 2nd Cavalry Regiment]]. His unit was stationed at [[Camp Stambaugh]]. He deserted two weeks later, as he was unable to adapt to the strict lifestyle, but was captured and [[court-martial]]ed. He was sentenced to two years hard labour, strapped to a [[ball and chain]], and imprisoned at [[Camp Stambaugh]]. He was held for four months and then released to return to his unit. His marksmanship skills were noticed, and he was assigned to the regular hunting parties leaving the post. He deserted again in May 1872.
==Return to Texas and further murders== Longley's travels for the rest of 1872 are unknown but by February 1873, he had returned to Texas, where he was accused of murdering another freedman in [[Bastrop County, Texas|Bastrop County]]. He then returned to live with his father's family in [[Bell County, Texas|Bell County]], Texas. In the summer of that year, [[Mason County, Texas|Mason County]] Sheriff, J. J. Finney, arrested Longley for murder and brought him to Austin to collect a reward. However, when the federal military reward was not forthcoming from state officials, Finney released Longley, possibly in exchange for a bribe from Longley's uncle, Alexander "Pres" Preston Longley of California.
On March 31, 1875, Longley shot his childhood friend, Wilson Anderson, dead with a shotgun. The murder was alleged to have been instigated by Longley's uncle, Caleb B. Longley, who had blamed Anderson for the death of his son, Cale, and urged Longley to take revenge. Longley then fled northward, accompanied by his brother, James Stockton Longley, who was later tried and acquitted of Anderson's murder. A new reward was posted for Longley's capture.
Under increasing pressure from law enforcement, Longley fled from place to place and used several aliases to avoid arrest. He briefly found work on a cotton farm, but he was forced to run again in November 1875, after murdering a hunting buddy named George Thomas with whom he had had a fistfight.
Longley committed another killing in [[Uvalde County, Texas|Uvalde County]], Texas in January 1876, when his attempted ambush of fellow outlaw, Lou Shroyer, turned into a gunfight. Shroyer shot Longley's horse from under him, but Longley shot Shroyer dead. This is the only known case in Longley's career where one of his victims returned fire.
Fleeing again, Longley went to east Texas and became a sharecropper for preacher, [[William R. Lay]]. Stability eluded him again, however, when Longley became rivals with Lay's nephew for the affections of a young woman. Longley beat up his rival, was subsequently jailed, and escaped. Longley blamed Lay for his brief imprisonment. On June 13, 1876, Longley rode out to his landlord's farm, found him milking a cow, and murdered him with a shotgun. Lay would be the last man known to be killed by Longley.
Longley then possibly went to [[Grayson County, Texas|Grayson County]], Texas, where two of his friends, Jim and Dick Sanders, were in jail. Longley broke them out, and the trio escaped, disarming deputy Matt Shelton when he tried to arrest them. Approximately one year later, deputy Matt Shelton confirmed this encounter. Longley then fled to [[Louisiana]].
==Capture and execution== [[File:William preston longley grave.jpg|thumb|rt|250px|Grave site of Bill Longley in Giddings City Cemetery]] On June 6, 1877, Longley was surrounded and arrested without incident by Nacogdoches County Sheriff, Milt Mast, and two deputies while he was residing in [[De Soto Parish, Louisiana|De Soto Parish]], Louisiana under the [[pseudonym|alias]] "Bill Jackson". He was returned to Texas, tried in the Lee County Court, and sentenced to hang for the murder of Wilson Anderson. His appeal was denied in March 1878. On October 11, 1878, Longley was executed by hanging in [[Giddings, Texas|Giddings]], Texas, only a few miles from his birthplace of Evergreen. His grave and a state historical marker are in Giddings City Cemetery.
He claimed to have killed thirty-two people, mostly of [[Hispanic]] and [[African American]] heritage.<ref>[http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025287/1878-10-17/ed-1/seq-2/;words=William+P+Longley ''Daily Globe article'']; Chronicling America: St. Paul, Minnesota; October 17, 1878, Image 2, column 7</ref>
== Legend, hoaxes, and tall tales ==
===Death hoax=== Years after the execution, Longley's father, Campbell, came forward in a press release stating that his son had ''not'' been executed. He claimed that a wealthy relative in [[California]] bribed the lawmen with $4,000, prompting them to rig a trick rope. They then staged the hanging and whisked the body away. The family even came up with alleged letters said to have been written by Longley from California. The legend spread, and many believed it for quite some time.{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}}
This prompted many historians to investigate. Finally, after confirming the gravesite of Longley, an exhumation of the human remains was performed. They were taken to the [[Smithsonian Institution]] in [[Washington D. C.]], where [[DNA]] tests were performed, along with a skull reconstruction. In June 2001, it was officially reported that the remains from the gravesite were indeed those of Bill Longley.<ref>Note: One datum in support of this conclusion was that the grave contained a Catholic medallion (The Miraculous Medal, an image of the Blessed Virgin Mary) that Longley was reportedly wearing on the day he was hanged. Longley had converted to Catholicism shortly before his death, as reported by the ''[[Scientific American Frontiers#Season 12 (2001-2002)| Scientific American Frontiers]]'' episode entitled, "Dead Men's Tales".</ref>
===Unverified claims=== Numerous myths and legends have grown up about Longley that cannot be verified by any contemporary source. Many of these legends trace back to tall tales that Longley himself told while imprisoned in Giddings in 1877. Some of these stories are probably false, while others could be true but lack any contemporary corroborating evidence. Longley's lies appear to have been motivated partly by his desire to rival [[John Wesley Hardin]]'s reputation as a killer.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Miller|first1=Rick|title=Boastful Bill Longley: Cold-blooded Texas Killer|website=www.historynet.com|publisher=Wild West Magazine|date=February 2002}}</ref> Longley was outraged when he found he was to be put to death, while Hardin was only sentenced to twenty-five years in prison.
The most clearly false story Longley told was of being captured and lynched in 1869 alongside one of [[Cullen Baker]]'s outlaw gang, surviving when a lucky shot severed the rope he had been hanged from, and then joining Baker's riders. As Baker was dead and his band dispersed at the time Longley claimed this happened, the story cannot be true.<ref>{{harvnb|Miller and Johnson|2011|p=27}}</ref>
There is no contemporaneous evidence to back claims that Longley murdered a black militiaman in Old Evergreen in 1866 for insulting his father, or that he shot eight black people in Lexington in 1867 to avenge the loss of a horse racing bet.<ref>{{harvnb|Miller and Johnson|2011|p=16-17}}</ref> Furthermore, Longley would have been 14 and 15 years old respectively at the time of the alleged incidents. True or false, the stories are consistent with Longley's well-established racist character; in his own words he "was taught to believe it was right to kill sassy negroes."<ref>{{harvnb|Miller and Johnson|2011|p=15}}</ref>
Longley's account of killing a [[trail boss]] named Rector while en route to Wyoming in 1870 is similarly of unknown veracity.<ref>{{harvnb|Miller and Johnson|2011|p=41}}</ref>
==Weapons of choice== Traditionally, Longley is said to have used a pair of Dance .44 revolvers; the Dance was a Texas-manufactured imitation of the [[Colt Dragoon]].<ref>William Foster-Harris (2007), ''The Look of the Old West: A Fully Illustrated Guide'', Skyhorse Publishing, Inc., {{ISBN|1-60239-024-X}}, p. 61.</ref> However, he used a shotgun to kill both Wilson Anderson and William Lay, his only murders for which his weapon is definitely known.
==In popular culture==
Longley is a major character in ''The Pistoleer,'' a novel by [[James Carlos Blake]] ([[Berkley Books]], NY, 1995).
In 1954, the [[actor]] [[Douglas Kennedy (actor)|Douglas Kennedy]] played Longley in an episode of [[Jim Davis (actor)|Jim Davis]]'s [[Television syndication|syndicated]] [[Western (genre)|western]] [[television series]], ''[[Stories of the Century]]''.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0710937/| title=''Stories of the Century'': "Bill Longley", May 20, 1954| publisher=[[Internet Movie Data Base]]| accessdate=September 16, 2012}}</ref>
In 1958, [[Steve McQueen]] played Longley in Season 2, Episode 23 of [[Tales of Wells Fargo]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0717113/| title=''Tales of Wells Fargo'': "Bill Longley", Feb 10, 1958| publisher=[[Internet Movie Data Base]]| accessdate=April 19, 2013}}</ref>
Longley is the title character in [[The Texan (TV series)|The Texan]], a television series starring [[Rory Calhoun]] which aired on [[CBS]] from [[1958 in television|1958]]-[[1960 in television|1960]], and portrayed Longley in an heroic role, a wanderer throughout the American West who assists those having trouble with the lawless element.<ref>Billy Hathorn, "Roy Bean, Temple Houston, Bill Longley, Ranald Mackenzie, Buffalo Bill, Jr., and the Texas Rangers: Depictions of West Texans in Series Television, 1955 to 1967", ''[[West Texas Historical Association|West Texas Historical Review]]'', Vol. 89 (2013), pp. 110-112</ref>
Longley figures prominently in [[Louis L'Amour]]'s 1959 [[novel]] ''The First Fast Draw'', a highly fictionalized version of Cullen Baker's life.
Texas singer/songwriter, Houston Marchman, wrote a song about Longley, ''Bill Longley,'' which is on his second CD ''Leavin' Dallas'' (1999).<ref name="All Country Tabs">{{cite web|url=http://www.allcountrytabs.com/tabs/houston-marchman/bill-longley-10703.html|title=Marchman Houston, Bill Longley Tabs|work=Bill Longley}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
* {{cite book|last1=Miller|first1=Rick|last2=Johnson|first2=David|title=Bloody Bill Longley: The Mythology of a Gunfighter|date=2011|publisher=University of North Texas Press|isbn=1-57441-305-8|pages=16–17}}
==Further reading== *Bartholomew, Ed Ellsworth. Wild Bill Longley: A Texas Hard-Case, Frontier Press of Texas, Houston, 1953 *Fuller, Henry Clay. The Adventures of Bill Longley, Galveston Daily News, Nacogdoches (Texas), September 16, 1877 *Sifakis, Carl. Encyclopedia of American Crime, Facts On File Inc., New York, 1982 *Miller, Rick. Bloody Bill Longley, Henington Publishing Company, 1996.
==External links== *{{Handbook of Texas|id=flo15|name=William Preston Longley}} *{{cite web |url=http://www.legendsofamerica.com/tx-billlongley.html |title=Wild Bill Longley - A Dangerous Man in Dangerous Times |website=Legendsofamerica.com |author=Kathy Weiser |accessdate=September 19, 2016}} *{{cite web |url=http://www.earlytexasfamilies.com/stories.legends/bill_longley.html |title=Wild Bill Longley |website=Earlytexasfamilies.com |author=Katherine Willingham Woerner |accessdate=September 19, 2016}} *{{cite web|url=http://montgomerystudio.com/lonestar/lsd_pg3.htm |title=Lone Star Diary - The Story of a Texas killer...This "Wild Bill" was no hero |accessdate=2005-05-31 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928134541/http://montgomerystudio.com/lonestar/lsd_pg3.htm |archivedate=2007-09-28 |df= }} by Murray Montgomery *{{cite web |url=http://www.texasescapes.com/DEPARTMENTS/Grave_Thoughts/BillLongley/BillLongley1.htm |title=Bill Longley, his hangings, his grave and Giddings Cemetery |website=Texasescapes.com |date=January 2001 |author=John Troesser |accessdate=September 19, 2016}} *{{cite web |url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/1400 |title=William Preston "Wild Bill" Longley (1851 - 1878) - Find A Grave Memorial |website=Findagrave.com |accessdate=September 19, 2016}} *{{cite web |url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82003389/1878-03-27/ed-1/seq-1/;words=Bill+Longley |title=1878 interview with Longley|newspaper=The Louisiana Democrat |date=March 27, 1878}} *{{cite web |url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026965/1878-10-31/ed-1/seq-1/;words=Baker+Cullen |title=1878 account of Longley career |newspaper=The Anderson Intelligencer |date=October 31, 1878}}

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}}
The '''celebrity-industrial complex''' is a social and economic construct which involves a symbiotic relationship between [[celebrity|celebrities]] and business corporations. First proposed by ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'' [[columnist]] [[Maureen Orth]] in her book, ''[[The Importance of Being Famous]]'' (2003), it is fueled both by the celebrities' seemingly continual search for fame and attention and the business corporations' search for catchy headlines and viable name brands that could be sustained by such celebrities.
In the celebrity-industrial complex, the celebrity either has a particular feature that is attractive to a public audience or is a victim of an occurrence that wins sympathy or condemnation from that same audience; this celebrity, for an initial period of time, becomes a subject of media scrutiny or marketing by properly funded media publication distributors. This media scrutiny, however, can often become a source of income for the celebrity, or the media scrutiny becomes an outlet of promotion for future manufactured publications or initiatives by the celebrities, and the media scrutiny around the celebrity expands to include coverage of such products.
The term "celebrity-industrial complex" is an homage to the much older term [[military–industrial complex]], which refers to a similar bilateral relationship between national militaries and industrial corporations which profit from each other.
==See also== * [[Military–industrial–media complex]] * [[Prison–industrial complex]] * [[Military–industrial complex]] * [[Politico-media complex]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Celebrity-Industrial Complex}} [[Category:Industries]] [[Category:Celebrity]]
{{Econ-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox rugby biography | name = Corra Dirksen | image = | birth_name = Cornelius Wilhelmus Dirksen | birth_date = 22 January 1938 | birth_place = [[Vereeniging]], [[South Africa]] | height = {{convert|1.84|m|ftin|abbr=on}} | weight = {{convert|84|kg|lb|abbr=on}} | nickname = | school = Vereeniging High | university = | relatives = [[Hanno Dirksen]] (nephew) | ru_position = [[Rugby union positions#Wing|Wing]] | currentclub = | ru_amateuryears = | ru_amateurclubs = | ru_clubyears = | ru_proclubs = | ru_clubcaps = | ru_clubpoints = | ru_province = [[Blue Bulls|Northern Transvaal]] | ru_provinceyears = ? | ru_provincecaps = ? | ru_provincepoints = ? | ru_nationalyears = 1963–68 | ru_nationalteam = [[South Africa national rugby union team|South Africa]] | ru_nationalcaps = 10 | ru_nationalpoints = (9) | pcupdate = | repupdate = }} '''Cornelius Wilhelmus "Corra" Dirken''' (born 22 January 1938 in Vereeniging, South Africa) is a former [[South Africa national rugby union team|South African]] [[Rugby union|rugby]] player. He won 10 caps and scored three tries.
==Rugby career== Dirksen made his international debut against [[Australia national rugby union team|Australia]] in 1963. The 1967 series against [[France national rugby union team|France]] was probably his finest hour, scoring all three of his test tries against them. The French were understandably quite wary of him throughout that series, dubbing him ''Le Monster'' (The Monster).
He played for the then Northern Transvaal (now Blue Bulls) and the Oostelikes (Easterns) club in Pretoria, which later merged with Adelaars to form Naka Bulls. After retiring from playing he qualified as a medical practitioner, and moved to Johannesburg, Krugersdorp.
==External links== * [http://www.genslin.us/bokke/PlayerData.aspx?PlayerID=153 Corra Dirksen] at the Springbok Rugby Hall of Fame
{{DEFAULTSORT:Dirksen, Corra}} [[Category:1938 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:South African rugby union players]] [[Category:Afrikaner people]] [[Category:Rugby union wings]] [[Category:South Africa international rugby union players]]

The '''Crazy Canucks''' was a group of [[FIS Alpine Ski World Cup|World Cup]] [[Alpine skiing|alpine ski racers]] from [[Canada]] who rose to prominence in the 1970s and 1980s. Jungle [[Jim Hunter (skier)|Jim Hunter]], [[Dave Irwin]], [[Dave Murray (skier)|Dave Murray]], [[Steve Podborski]], and [[Ken Read]] earned themselves a reputation for fast and seemingly reckless skiing in the [[Downhill (ski competition)|downhill]] event.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1066985/index.htm |magazine=Sports Illustrated |title=Wild and crazy guys |last=Ballard |first=Sarah |date=January 27, 1988}}</ref>
These five men earned their title "Crazy Canucks" from ski journalist and World Cup co-founder [[Serge Lang (skiing)|Serge Lange]], who after watching their different styles came up with the name that caught on with sports journalists throughout the skiing world<ref>"[http://www.daveirwinfoundation.org/crazycanucks.html]" - Dave Irwin Foundation "The Crazy Canucks" - Retrieved 4 April 2013</ref> Other similar nicknames included "[[Kamikaze]] Canadians."<ref name=kmkecnd>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=xH0xAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5aEFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5240%2C2441998|newspaper=Montreal Gazette |agency=''The Canadian'' (insert magazine) |last=Scammell |first=Ron |title=The Kamikaze Canadians |date=December 9, 1978 |page=10 }}</ref>
These five men were at the top of their game and better known in Europe than in North America. Once they hit the European hills, they consistently challenged the Europeans on the World Cup circuit at a level previously unseen.<ref>"[http://www.cbc.ca/archives/categories/sports/skiing/the-crazy-canucks-canadas-skiing-heroes/the-crazy-canucks-more-famous-in-europe.html]" - CBC Digital Archives "The Crazy Canucks, more famous in Europe". Retrieved 4 April 2013</ref>
Four of the five "Crazy Canucks" live on today. Dave Murray, 37, died of skin cancer on October 23, 1990.<ref>"[http://go.galegroup.com/ps/retrieve.do?retrieveFormat=PDF_FROM_CALLISTO&inPS=true&prodId=AONE&userGroupName=utoronto_main&workId=PI-1565-2009-DEC00-IDSI-28.JPG%7CPI-1565-2009-DEC00-IDSI-29.JPG%7CPI-1565-2009-DEC00-IDSI-30.JPG%7CPI-1565-2009-DEC00-IDSI-31.JPG%7CPI-1565-2009-DEC00-IDSI-32.JPG&docId=GALE%7CA227182622&callistoContentSet=PER&isAcrobatAvailable=false]" - Crazy Cool "Legend of the Crazy Canucks - January 2010. Retrieved 4 April 2013</ref>
In 2006, it was announced that the four original Crazy Canucks would be receiving stars on [[Canada's Walk of Fame]]. They would all be inducted as one group. The only other skier on the walk is Canadian skiing legend [[Nancy Greene]].
==TV film== ''Crazy Canucks'' was a [[TV movie]] named after and based on the history of the team. It was released in [[2004 in film|2004]] in [[Canada]]. The film was directed by Randy Bradshaw and starred Sandy Robson (Hunter), [[Lucas Bryant]] (Read), [[Curtis Harrison]] (Podborski), [[Kyle Labine]] (Murray) and [[Robert Tinkler]] (Irwin).
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20050228035107/http://www.canski.org/e/html/news/e_newsdetail.asp?articleID=1288&articleTypeID=2 The founding of the Canadian Alpine Ski Team] *[http://www.cbc.ca/archives/categories/sports/skiing/the-crazy-canucks-canadas-skiing-heroes/topic---the-crazy-canucks-canadas-skiing-heroes.html CBC Digital Archives – The Crazy Canucks: Canada's skiing heroes] *[https://archive.is/20140129231544/http://www.sportshall.ca/collections/ken-read-collection/4304/ken-read-collection-5/ Canada's Sports Hall of Fame] – photo of Crazy Canucks at 1976 Winter Olympics – (Read, Hunter, Irwin, Murray) *Crazy Canucks [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0391890/ IMDb]

In November 2018 Dr. Ezcurra was elected to join the ranks of Corresponding Members of the Mexican Academy of Sciences.
revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Exequiel Ezcurra | image = File:E. Ezcurra Isla San Pedro Mártir.jpg | caption = Dr. Exequiel Ezcurra on Isla San Pedro Mártir | birth_date = March 21, 1950 | birth_place = Buenos Aires, Argentina | nationality = Mexican | occupation = Ecologist & Conservationist }}
'''Exequiel Ezcurra''' (born March 21, 1950, Buenos Aires, Argentina) is a plant ecologist and conservationist. His highly interdisciplinary work spans desert plant ecology, mangroves, island biogeography, sea birds, fisheries, oceanography, and deep-sea ecosystems.
He is currently the Director of the University of California Institute for Mexico and the United States ([[University of California Institute for Mexico and the United States|UC MEXUS]]), as well as a Professor of Plant Ecology at [[University of California, Riverside|UC Riverside]]. Ezcurra is also on the board of [[Ensenada Center for Scientific Research and Higher Education|CICESE]], the Ensenada Center for Scientific Research and Higher Education.
==Education== Ezcurra received his B.S. from the [[University of Buenos Aires]] in 1973. He then received an M.Sc. and a Ph.D. in Plant Biology from [[Bangor University|University College of North Wales]] in 1978 and 1984, respectively. At Bangor, one of his primary mentors was Peter Greig-Smith, a renowned ecologist whose academic lineage of mentors can be traced back to [[Charles Darwin]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Peter Greig-Smith|url=http://www.oxfordbibliographies.com/view/document/obo-9780199830060/obo-9780199830060-0089.xml|website=Oxford Bibliographies, Oxford University Press, UK}}</ref>
==Career== Ezcurra was the Principal Researcher in charge of the Laboratory of Community Ecology at National Autonomous University of Mexico ([[National Autonomous University of Mexico|UNAM]]) from 1987 to 1998. In 1998, Ezcurra moved to San Diego, California to take on the roles of Director of the Biodiversity Research Center of the Californias, and Deputy Director of Research and Collections at the [[San Diego Natural History Museum]].<ref>{{cite web|title=San Diego Natural History Museum Welcomes Dr. Exequiel Ezcurra as Director of the Biodiversity Research Center for the Californias|url=http://laprensa-sandiego.org/archieve/may01/museum.htm|website=La Prensa San Diego}}</ref> In 2001, Ezcurra left US to accept the position of President of Mexico’s National Institute of Ecology and Climate Change (''Instituto Nacional de Ecología y Cambio Climático''), independent research branch of Mexico’s Ministry of the Environment and Natural Resources (Secretaría de Medio Ambiente y Recursos Naturales) from 2001 to 2003.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Guillén|first1=Fedro Carlos|title=Instituto Nacional de Ecología. Quince años de políticas ambientales en México. Memoria testimonial|date=2007|publisher=Instituto Nacional de Ecología|isbn=9688178799|page=141|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GTMw5a0D84MC&pg=PA141&lpg=PA141&dq=exequiel+ezcurra+instituto+nacional+de+ecologia&source=bl&ots=iB1IGxZHmA&sig=10u1j4CWDQbDYJ2ckQFtgSnBqgw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwif8sTh87_TAhWrrlQKHXtVDmYQ6AEIPjAD#v=onepage&q=exequiel%20ezcurra%20instituto%20nacional%20de%20ecologia&f=false}}</ref>
Ezcurra returned to the San Diego Natural History Museum where he remained until 2008, when he assumed his current roles as Professor of Plant Ecology at UC Riverside, and Director of UC MEXUS (the University of California Institute for Mexico and the United States). Ezcurra has also served as President of the Board of the Mexican National Commission of Protected Natural Areas ([[Mexican Protected Natural Areas|CONANP]]),<ref>{{cite web|title=Comunicados de Prensa|url=http://www.conanp.gob.mx/difusion/comunicado.php?id_subcontenido=277|website=CONANP}}</ref> and Scientific Chair for the [[CITES]] Convention.<ref>{{cite web|title=Exequiel Ezcurra|url=http://www.worldwildlife.org/leaders/exequiel-ezcurra--2|website=World Wildlife Fund}}</ref>
As an active member of the Mexican National System of Researchers (''[[Sistema Nacional de Investigadores]]''), Ezcurra also lectures and is a graduate adviser at a number of Mexican universities and research centers. In addition, he is an adjunct professor at the [[Scripps Institution of Oceanography]].
Other achievements from Dr. Ezcurra’s 40-year research career, include developing the first environmental impact assessments in Mexico, playing a central part in the establishment of multiple natural protected areas (including the [[El Pinacate y Gran Desierto de Altar Biosphere Reserve]] and the Islands of the Gulf of California). Dr. Ezcurra also played a key role in promoting the creation of the [[California condor]] release program in Baja California, and initiating the successful restoration of Guadalupe Island in the Mexican Pacific.<ref>{{cite web|title=Researchers|url=http://nextgensd.com/researcher/exequiel-ezcurra/|website=N-Gen}}</ref>
===Research=== Ezcurra has published more than 170 research papers, books, and book chapters. These include three books about the Gulf of California and its surrounding islands, and a large number of essays and articles for newspapers and popular journals.<ref>{{cite web|title=Exequiel Ezcurra|url=https://scholar.google.com/citations?hl=en&user=RyB1baIAAAAJ&view_op=list_works&sortby=pubdate|website=Google Scholar|publisher=Google}}</ref> Ezcurra's areas of research include conservation science, the ecology and biogeography of coastal deserts, land-ocean interactions and their impact on both marine and terrestrial environments, the application of mathematical modeling in ecology and conservation, and the management of natural resources in areas under traditional use. In his career as a plant ecologist, Dr. Ezcurra has worked to describe the relationships between marine and terrestrial ecological systems, and the processes that drive highly productive environments. His academic works include a range of highly-cited papers covering desert plant ecology,<ref>See, e.g. [http://ezcurralab.ucr.edu/eezcurra/publications/papers/14.pdf Ezcurra et al. 1987]; [http://ezcurralab.ucr.edu/eezcurra/publications/papers/30.pdf Valiente-Banuet et al. 1991]; [http://ezcurralab.ucr.edu/eezcurra/publications/papers/81.pdf Caso et al. 2007]; [http://ezcurralab.ucr.edu/eezcurra/publications/papers/126.pdf Delgado-Fernández et al. 2016]</ref> mangroves,<ref>See, e.g. [http://ezcurralab.ucr.edu/eezcurra/publications/papers/21.pdf López-Portillo & Ezcurra 1989]; [http://ezcurralab.ucr.edu/eezcurra/publications/papers/86.pdf Aburto-Oropeza et al. 2008]; [http://ezcurralab.ucr.edu/eezcurra/publications/papers/95.pdf López-Medellín et al. 2011]; [http://ezcurralab.ucr.edu/eezcurra/publications/papers/125.pdf Ezcurra et al. 2016]</ref> island biogeography,<ref>See, e.g. [http://ezcurralab.ucr.edu/eezcurra/publications/papers/85.pdf Garcillán et al. 2008], [http://ezcurralab.ucr.edu/eezcurra/publications/papers/108.pdf Velarde et al. 2014], [http://ezcurralab.ucr.edu/eezcurra/publications/papers/109.pdf Wilder et al. 2014]</ref> sea birds,<ref>See, e.g. [http://ezcurralab.ucr.edu/eezcurra/publications/papers/71.pdf Velarde et al. 2004], [http://ezcurralab.ucr.edu/eezcurra/publications/papers/102.pdf Velarde et al. 2013], [http://ezcurralab.ucr.edu/eezcurra/publications/papers/113.pdf Velarde et al. 2015]</ref> fisheries, oceanography, and deep sea ecosystems.
One of the principal strengths and contributions of Ezcurra’s ecological research is the ability to document the individual components of an ecosystem and then synthesize these components at a regional landscape level. Examples of this approach include:
===Conservation=== Dr. Ezcurra is known for translating scientific research into tangible, positive conservation outcomes. His work has influenced policy at the highest levels of government. It has also created strong and lasting collaborations between the governments of Mexico and the United States, as well as between academic institutions and non-governmental organizations from both countries. Specific instances include: * The first Environmental Impact Assessments for impacts to mangrove forests on Mexico's Yucatán Peninsula * The establishment of El Pinacate and Gran Desierto de Altar Biosphere Reserve in 1993 and its subsequent classification as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2013,<ref>{{cite web|title=El Pinacate and Gran Desierto de Altar Biosphere Reserve|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1410|website=UNESCO}}</ref> * The establishment of the Islands and Protected Areas of the Gulf of California UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2005.<ref>{{cite web|title=World-class Ecologist Appointed Director of University of California Institute for Mexico and the United States|url=http://newsroom.ucr.edu/1966|website=UCR Newsroom}}</ref> * The establishment of [[Cabo Pulmo National Park|Cabo Pulmo Natural Protected area]], in Baja California Sur, Mexico, in 1995.<ref>{{cite book|title=Programa de Conservación y Manejo Parque Nacional Cabo Pulmo|publisher=CONANP-SEMANART|url=http://www.conanp.gob.mx/que_hacemos/pdf/programas_manejo/cabo.pdf}}</ref>
===Science Popularization=== From the outset of his career, Ezcurra has pursued the dissemination of science to the general public through his writing, museum work, and other creative media. Some notable examples include his roles as the: * Science script writer, producer, and narrator of the award winning giant-screen film "Ocean Oasis" (1999)<ref>{{cite web|title=Exequiel Ezcurra|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1011073/|website=IMDB}}</ref> * San Diego Natural History Museum exhibit curator of "Desert and Sea - Evolutionary Processes and Biodiversity of the Pacific Coastal Deserts of North America" (1999) and "Water: The California Story" (2008) * [[American Museum of Natural History]] international exhibit curator of "Water: H2O = Life" (2007) * Story-script writer and narrator of "The Natural Numbers, Sardines” [[infographic]] video,<ref>{{cite web|title=Sardines|url=http://thenaturalnumbers.org/sardines.html|website=The Natural Numbers}}</ref> as well as other Natural Number videos including “Gold”,<ref>{{cite web|title=Gold|url=http://thenaturalnumbers.org/gold.html|website=The Natural Numbers}}</ref> “Free-flowing Rivers”,<ref>{{cite web|title=Free-flowing Rivers|url=http://thenaturalnumbers.org/free-flowing-rivers.html|website=The Natural Numbers}}</ref> “Mangroves”,<ref>{{cite web|title=Mangroves|url=http://thenaturalnumbers.org/mangroves.html|website=The Natural Numbers}}</ref> “Spawning aggregations”,<ref>{{cite web|title=Spawning Aggregations|url=http://thenaturalnumbers.org/spawning-aggregations.html|website=The Natural Numbers}}</ref> and “Marine Ecotourism”.<ref>{{cite web|title=Marine Ecotourism|url=http://thenaturalnumbers.org/marine-ecoturism.html|website=The Natural Numbers}}</ref>
==Honors & Awards== *1993, Faustino Miranda Medal from [[National Autonomous University of Mexico|UNAM]] for merit in ecological research *1993, Conservación Award from [[Pronatura México|Pronatura]] *1994, Julian Hayden Award from the Sonoran Alliance<ref>{{cite web|title=The Researchers|url=http://www.sdnhm.org/oceanoasis/behindthescenes/researchers.html|website=San Diego Natural History Museum}}</ref> *1994, [[Society for Conservation Biology]] Award *2001, [[Wildscreen]] Award for the film “Ocean Oasis” *2001, [[Jackson Hole Wildlife Film Festival]] for the film “Ocean Oasis”<ref>{{cite web|title=Ocean Oasis Wins Award at Jackson Hole Wildlife Festival|url=http://www.bigmoviezone.com/articles/index.html?uniq=70|website=Big Movie Zone}}</ref> *2005-2008, Pew Fellowship in the field of Marine Conservation<ref>{{cite web|title=Marine Fellows|url=http://www.pewtrusts.org/en/projects/marine-fellows/fellows-directory/2006/exequiel-ezcurra|website=Pew Trust}}</ref> *2017, Fellow of the [[Ecological Society of America]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Ecological Society of America announces 2017 Fellows|url=https://www.esa.org/esa/ecological-society-of-america-announces-2017-fellows/|website=Ecological Society of America}}</ref> *2018, Corresponding member of the [[Mexican Academy of Sciences|Mexican Academy of Sciences]]
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}

{{Infobox person |name = Frank Taffel |image = Ftaffelfn.jpg |image_size = 130px |caption = Frank Taffel |birth_date = March 10, 1877 |birth_place = [[Chervonohrad#Krystynopol Jews|Krystynopol]] (now [[Chervonohrad]], Ukraine) |death_date = July 7, 1947 |death_place = [[Savannah, Georgia]] |other_names = Shrage Fyvel Tafel |known_for = journalism, founding synagogue |occupation = journalist, synagogue founder, entrepreneur |nationality = US |spouse = {{ubl|Minke Frostig (1901–1945, her death)|Ruth Rosenfeld (1945–1947, his death)}} }} '''Frank Taffel''' (né Shrage Fyvel Tafel, [[Chervonohrad#Krystynopol Jews|Krystynopol]], then [[Galicia (Eastern Europe)|Galicia]], [[Austria-Hungary]], now [[Chervonohrad]], [[Ukraine]], March 10, 1877; died 7 July 1947, [[Savannah, Georgia]], age 70) was a journalist, a founder of [[Congregation Beth Jacob (Atlanta)]], and an advocate of Jewish causes.
==Immigration and life in Atlanta== Taffel, son of Jacob Tafel, a dairy farmer, and Esther Verner, emigrated from [[Galicia (Eastern Europe)|Galicia]] (then Austria-Hungary, now part of Ukraine), entered the US from [[Montreal]] 1907, and became a US citizen, June 26, 1922. In 1924 he founded Atlanta's Fulton Auto Exchange, which rebuilt and sold used trucks, and he was also a commodities speculator. Taffel was a founder of [[Congregation Beth Jacob (Atlanta)]], and was one of eleven petitioners for the original charter.<ref>''Petition for Charter. Congregation Beth Jacob''. Southern Israelite. June 18, 1943 p 6.</ref> The Frank Taffel Sanctuary is named in his honor. Taffel frequently spoke in public on Jewish causes, and was president of the [[Nahum Sokolov]] Literary Society.<ref>Report on un-American propaganda will be made by Frank Taffel. ''The Atlanta Constitution''; January 14, 1938 p2</ref><ref>Jews are invited to Passover fête. The Atlanta Constitution April 16, 1938, p 6</ref><ref>Anshe Sfard plans rally next Sunday. The Atlanta Constitution April 14, 1938 p 16</ref> He wrote for ''[[The Atlanta Journal-Constitution]],'' The [[Macon Telegraph]]<ref>Frank Taffel. Jews as smokescreens. Macon Telegraph. Sunday April 12, 1936 p4</ref> and was Atlanta correspondent for the ''[[Jewish Morning Journal]]'' of New York.<ref>Frank Taffel. Modern Palestine Created By Jews. The Atlanta Constitution; Aug 1, 1937 pg. 11A</ref><ref>Rabbi Conducts Exercises. Macon Telegraph. Feb 12, 1935 p 6</ref> In addition, he was president of the Atlanta [[HIAS|Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society]], and in 1937, over radio station [[WGST]] in Atlanta, described the work of the organization.<ref>Hebrew Sheltering. Southern Israelite. Aug. 27, 1937, page 8</ref>
[[File:Taffelgrave.jpg|thumb|right|Grave of Frank and Minnie Taffel at [[Greenwood Cemetery (Atlanta)|Greenwood Cemetery, Atlanta]]]] Taffel died on a trip to [[Savannah, Georgia]].
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.bethjacobatlanta.org Congregation Beth Jacob, Atlanta]
{{authority control}}

[[Makerere University]]
{{small|([[Bachelor of Science]] in mathematics & physics)}}
[[University of Buckingham]]
{{small|([[Master of Business Administration]] in accounting & finance)}} | occupation = Accountant & [[entrepreneur]] | years_active = 1997 — present | nationality = Ugandan | citizenship = Uganda | residence = [[Kampala]], Uganda | known_for = Finance and entrepreneurship | networth = | home_town = [[Kampala]] | title = Director of finance
[[Cipla Quality Chemical Industries Limited| CIPLAQCIL]] | spouse = }} '''Frederick Mutebi Kitaka''', sometimes referred to as '''Frederick Kitaka Mutebi''', is a [[Uganda]]n [[physicist]], [[mathematician]], accountant, [[entrepreneur]], and [[industrialist]]. He is the executive director of finance of [[Cipla Quality Chemical Industries Limited]] (CIPLAQCIL), a Ugandan limited liability company. CIPLAQCIL is the only [[Sub-Saharan]] pharmaceutical company that is licensed to manufacture triple therapy antiretroviral medication. He is also a shareholder in the company and sits on its [[board of directors]].{{cite web | url=http://www.ciplaqcil.co.ug/about-us/board-of-directors | title=Board of Directors: Frederick Mutebi Kitaka - Executive Director & Chief Finance Officer | accessdate=28 March 2015 | last=CQCIL | publisher=[[Cipla Quality Chemical Industries Limited]] (CQCIL)}} ==Education== Kitaka was educated at [[St. Mary's College Kisubi]],{{Citation needed|date=September 2016}} a boys-only boarding middle and high school located in [[Wakiso District]] in the [[Central Region, Uganda|Central Region]] of [[Uganda]]. He studied [[mathematics]] and [[physics]] at [[Makerere University]], graduating with a [[Bachelor of Science]] degree. He also holds a [[Master of Business Administration]] in accounting and financial management from the [[University of Buckingham]]. ==Work history== From 1994 until 2002, Kitaka worked as the [[financial controller]] at Coopers Uganda Limited, a company that later rebranded to MTK Holdings Limited. From 2002 until 2005, he worked as the director of finance at [[Quality Chemicals Limited]]. In 2005, he became the [[chief financial officer]] at [[Quality Chemical Industries Limited]]. He also sits on the board of [[Buganda Investments and Commercial Undertakings Limited]]{{cite web | url=http://www.bicul.co.ug/#!board-members/ujlrb | title=BICUL Board Members | accessdate=25 July 2016 | date=25 July 2016 | publisher=Buganda Investments and Commercial Undertakings Limited | author=BICUL | location=Kampala}} ==See also== *[[Cipla]] *[[Emmanuel Katongole (businessman)]] *[[Francis Kitaka]] *[[George Baguma]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.ciplaqcil.co.ug/ Cipla Quality Chemical Industries Limited] {{DEFAULTSORT:Kitaka, Fred}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Ugandan accountants]] [[Category:Ganda people]] [[Category:Makerere University alumni]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Buckingham]] [[Category:Chief financial officers]] [[Category:Ugandan Roman Catholics]]
